question: What are the common metrics shared between Coal Operations and Iron & Steel Producers industries, if any?
optionA: EM-CO-110a.1 and EM-IS-110a.1, which are both about gross global Scope 1 emissions and percentage covered under emissions-limiting regulations.
optionB: There are no common metrics shared between the two industries.
optionC: EM-CO-110a.2 and EM-IS-110a.2, which are both about discussion of strategy/plan to manage Scope 1 emissions and emission reduction targets.
optionD: EM-CO-140a.1 and EM-IS-140a.1, which are both about total fresh water withdrawn, percentage recycled, and percentage in regions with high water stress.
optionE: EM-CO-420a.1 and EM-IS-430a.1, which are about sensitivity of reserves to price scenarios and managing supply chain risks respectively.
reference_text: For Coal Operations, EM-CO-110a.2 is: 'Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets'

For Iron & Steel Producers, EM-IS-110a.2 is: 'Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets'
pairing_explanation: These extractive industries have substantial environmental impacts, including emissions, land use, and water consumption, making them critical to compare in sustainability reporting.

question: When preparing sustainability reports, how do the metrics for measuring Greenhouse Gas Emissions differ between the Coal Operations and Iron & Steel Producers industries?
optionA: There is no difference in the metrics for measuring Greenhouse Gas Emissions between these two industries.
optionB: Coal Operations has an additional metric for estimated carbon dioxide emissions embedded in proven coal reserves.
optionC: Iron & Steel Producers has an additional metric for total energy consumed broken down by source.
optionD: Coal Operations measures Scope 2 emissions while Iron & Steel Producers measures Scope 1 emissions.
optionE: Coal Operations measures emissions reductions while Iron & Steel Producers measures emissions increases.
reference_text: | TOPIC | METRIC | CATEGORY | UNIT OF MEASURE | CODE |
| Greenhouse Gas Emissions | Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under emissions-limiting regulations | Quantitative | Metric tons (t) CO₂-e, Percentage (%) | EM-CO-110a.1 |

| Greenhouse Gas Emissions | Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets | Discussion and Analysis | n/a | EM-CO-110a.2 |
| Reserves Valuation & Capital Expenditures | Estimated carbon dioxide emissions embedded in proven coal reserves | Quantitative | Metric tons (t) CO₂-e | EM-CO-420a.2 |
| Greenhouse Gas Emissions | Gross global Scope 1 emissions, percentage covered under emissions-limiting regulations | Quantitative | Metric tons (t) CO₂-e, Percentage (%) | EM-IS-110a.1 |

| Greenhouse Gas Emissions | Discussion of long-term and short-term strategy or plan to manage Scope 1 emissions, emissions reduction targets, and an analysis of performance against those targets | Discussion and Analysis | n/a | EM-IS-110a.2 |
pairing_explanation: These extractive industries have substantial environmental impacts, including emissions, land use, and water consumption, making them critical to compare in sustainability reporting.
